componenttext: Our next question is coming from Chris Turnure of JPMorgan.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we could talk a little bit about the supply set of the business and x the PPA if you just look at the performance over the past couple of quarters I think specifically excluding the change in capacity prices and excluding the change in
componenttext: I was wondering if we could talk a little bit about the supply set of the business and x the PPA if you just look at the performance over the past couple of quarters I think specifically excluding the change in capacity prices and excluding the change in the volume. You had a pretty noticeable improvement there despite a decline in commodity prices. Could you just maybe flush that out a little bit more and give us color there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start and I'll let Donny add to it. During 2015, we talked with you about our cash flow improvement program. Much of that was focused on the competitive business and much of that was focused on getting our competitiveness to the point where it contin
componenttext: I'll start and I'll let Donny add to it. During 2015, we talked with you about our cash flow improvement program. Much of that was focused on the competitive business and much of that was focused on getting our competitiveness to the point where it continues to be cash flow positive and has no need for any cash from the parent through 2018, at current energy prices as we know them. So part of that was also targeted at the FFO from that generation business, so we reduced O&M expenditures which contributed to some of what you're seeing there. So that's kind of from an operational perspective. The thing that Jim Lasch and his generation team have done to improve the competitiveness. I'll let Donny talk a little bit about the commodity side.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just add obviously, we have taken a position starting after the POLR vortex in '14 to derisk the business and to move away from weather sensitive load. You'll recall in the first quarter for '15, we have what's been referred to as the Siberian Express a
componenttext: I just add obviously, we have taken a position starting after the POLR vortex in '14 to derisk the business and to move away from weather sensitive load. You'll recall in the first quarter for '15, we have what's been referred to as the Siberian Express and while it was not nearly as significant of an impact to FES as the POLR vortex, it still has some impact. I'm happy to report that in the past quarter, although we've had very mild weather, the fact that we have much less weather sensitive load, our results were pretty much in line with our expectations from a sales perspective.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Donny and his team are doing a fantastic job running that business too. Back in February when we had Mansfield off for 2 weeks, the entire plant off, there were several sell side notes that suggested that load was down and we were going to have a bad quar
componenttext: Donny and his team are doing a fantastic job running that business too. Back in February when we had Mansfield off for 2 weeks, the entire plant off, there were several sell side notes that suggested that load was down and we were going to have a bad quarter. In reality that's part of how we're dispatching those units differently. So we don't run them when we can't make money with them. So I talked in my remarks about that save us fuel, so Donny is doing a great job at looking at every day, every hour, how do we maximize that business under some very difficult economic times.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean to that point, is there anything that we should think about historically that force you to run units that were uneconomic such as mandatory take or pay coal contracts or something of that nature that would be rolling off this year or in the future
componenttext: I mean to that point, is there anything that we should think about historically that force you to run units that were uneconomic such as mandatory take or pay coal contracts or something of that nature that would be rolling off this year or in the future to kind of provide a tailwind for your numbers all equal or am I barking up the wrong tree there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Donny.
componenttext: Go ahead, Donny.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've had coal contracts in place for a lot of years that gives us significant flexibility. This isn't really something new for us. I think the degree is much greater now but you recall back in 2000 -- I believe it was 2012, around August 2012, we took th
componenttext: We've had coal contracts in place for a lot of years that gives us significant flexibility. This isn't really something new for us. I think the degree is much greater now but you recall back in 2000 -- I believe it was 2012, around August 2012, we took the entire Sammis plant down and kept it offline through December. So it's not really new. I think the difference is with the weak -- incredibly weak forward day ahead market that we've seen, it calls in more economic dispatch than perhaps what we've seen in the past.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then shifting gears to transmission again. The rejection by New Jersey of your utility status for the MAIT request. It would seem on the surface to be a significant setback but your comments have indicated that you're going to continue to
componenttext: Okay, great. And then shifting gears to transmission again. The rejection by New Jersey of your utility status for the MAIT request. It would seem on the surface to be a significant setback but your comments have indicated that you're going to continue to push forward and you think it's very important. Can you may be characterized how important the New Jersey part of the MAIT program is to the transmission spend and the levels going forward and growth going forward and the timing that you have the setback. Has it been kind of adjusted at all in New Jersey?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first I would say, I think MAIT is very important for customers in New Jersey and we have to do a better good job of helping the BPU understand why it's important. We've done that in our latest filing and we'll continue to work with them the benefit ac
componenttext: So first I would say, I think MAIT is very important for customers in New Jersey and we have to do a better good job of helping the BPU understand why it's important. We've done that in our latest filing and we'll continue to work with them the benefit across the finish line. If we don't, then we'll look at options to implement MAIT in Pennsylvania potentially but as far as your real question, in terms of how does it affect our transmission investment strategy, we've got 2 more years of Energizing the Future. We've got projects beyond that inside ATSI and TrAILCo that we can continue to move forward with. I don't see MAIT being crucial at all to our transmission investment strategy. I see it as a way to implement that transmission investment strategy in a way where we can lower the cost of capital and do it in a way that's better for customers and create more transparency for our investors. That's how I see it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is coming from Stephen Byrd of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question is coming from Stephen Byrd of Morgan Stanley.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been addressed. I just wanted to focus on the Pennsylvania revenue request. When I look at the Appendix, it looks like the customer bill impacts can be relatively significant. I think one of the jurisdictions it's about 18% if I'
componenttext: Most of my questions have been addressed. I just wanted to focus on the Pennsylvania revenue request. When I look at the Appendix, it looks like the customer bill impacts can be relatively significant. I think one of the jurisdictions it's about 18% if I'm reading the page correctly. Is there a way to phase that or otherwise lessen the overall bill impact and are there other presence we can look to in Pennsylvania in terms of just how to think about that? It seems like a fairly sizable rate impact?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, this is Jim. I would say that as we said earlier in our comments and Chuck said in his, that this will bring the average residential bill in Pennsylvania up to about what's average within the state. You'll recall we went a number of years without
componenttext: Stephen, this is Jim. I would say that as we said earlier in our comments and Chuck said in his, that this will bring the average residential bill in Pennsylvania up to about what's average within the state. You'll recall we went a number of years without increasing our rates in the state of Pennsylvania. It's also being offset by a -- from a customer perspective, it's being offset by a reduction in their overall energy component of the bill. So I don't view this as something that's going to be -- what would be described as a rate shock issue. As far as your early -- your request no, I don't -- we don't see any mechanism out there where we would phase this in. This is just a normal type of request that we would have and again, as Leila pointed out earlier, there's very stringent energy efficiency requirements in the state of Pennsylvania which is decreasingly used. So we're more required to go in and pop these rates. So that's where we're looking at it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And in the terms of the magnitude of the benefit from lower energy costs. Is there a way for us to get a sense for the magnitude of that benefit?
componenttext: Understood. And in the terms of the magnitude of the benefit from lower energy costs. Is there a way for us to get a sense for the magnitude of that benefit?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you can probably look at where our power prices have gone over the last few years and as Donny mentioned, holds up power prices have fallen $3 already this year, so I think there was a period of time when run the clock power prices were in the $50
componenttext: I think you can probably look at where our power prices have gone over the last few years and as Donny mentioned, holds up power prices have fallen $3 already this year, so I think there was a period of time when run the clock power prices were in the $50 plus range and if you look at the forwards out there right now, over the next 3 years, they're probably closer to the $30 range.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Ashar Khan of Visio.

componenttext: I just wanted to help in terms of trying to measure these rate cases in terms of earnings potential. componenttext: I'll answer it at a high-level and if you want details, then I'll let Leila and Jim fill in. As filed in effect January of next year, the JCP&L case is about $0.20 a share and a Pennsylvania cases combined is about $0.40 a share.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: I understand you're struggling with it and I understand that the estimates are all over the board for what does ESP means and believe me, as soon as we can give you clarification, we plan to do that. Once we have an answer from FERC, we will tell you what the value of this company is going forward with the ESP. If we don't have an answer, then we're going to give you 2016 guidance without the ESP and I apologize that we're leaving you hanging out there but it's just too big a moving part for us to speculate on the outcome.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just most of the questions have been answered, just want to follow up. As the company is looking to transition more to a regulated utility, thoughts on maybe rate basing or getting some type of cost service return on -- on other power plants particularly
componenttext: Just most of the questions have been answered, just want to follow up. As the company is looking to transition more to a regulated utility, thoughts on maybe rate basing or getting some type of cost service return on -- on other power plants particularly Pleasant or Mansfield?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of what we are a regulated utility. 90%-plus of our earnings today come from our regulated operations. What we're talking about is growth in investment inside that regulated utility. We filed our integrated resource plan with West Virginia. I
componenttext: Well, first of what we are a regulated utility. 90%-plus of our earnings today come from our regulated operations. What we're talking about is growth in investment inside that regulated utility. We filed our integrated resource plan with West Virginia. I think later this year, they'll start taking a look at it seriously and it's up to the West Virginia Commission to decide what would be the appropriate solution. Obviously, we have a model in place with Harrison and we think that is something they ought to look at.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Pennsylvania, is there a similar filing or similar thought process or just West Virginia?
componenttext: In Pennsylvania, is there a similar filing or similar thought process or just West Virginia?

componenttext: Just West Virginia.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michael Lapides of Goldman Sachs..

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have you ever put or can you discuss what you think the scale of the main investment could be over a multiyear time. I mean should we think about it similar to the size and scale of what ATSI and TrAIL have been. I know lots of TrAIL was just 1 big projec
componenttext: Have you ever put or can you discuss what you think the scale of the main investment could be over a multiyear time. I mean should we think about it similar to the size and scale of what ATSI and TrAIL have been. I know lots of TrAIL was just 1 big project but ATSI was a series of projects. Is it something that could be significantly smaller or significantly bigger? Just trying to get arms around how you're thinking about the size, scale and scope of MAIT could be.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, let me clarify it again. We've told you we have over $15 billion of transmission projects that our teams already identified on our existing 24,000 miles of transmission system. Those projects can be executed with or without MAIT. MAIT is
componenttext: So first of all, let me clarify it again. We've told you we have over $15 billion of transmission projects that our teams already identified on our existing 24,000 miles of transmission system. Those projects can be executed with or without MAIT. MAIT is a vehicle to improve the recovery mechanism from a transparency perspective for investors and lower the cost to capital to make those investments more efficient for customers. That's all MAIT is. It doesn't stop us from moving forward with our transmission investment program. As far as the scale of the program, we'll talk to you about that once we know the base of the company that we're operating on after we get a resolution on the CSP because it's more driven by our capability of raising the cash and in likely some equity to fund it. So we'll tell you about that once we know those answers.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it  okay. I'm just trying to get my arms around -- I mean, MAIT -- the transmission in the Eastern part of your service territories seems like a huge opportunity in terms of the rate base growth there. I'm just trying to get my arms around kind of the
componenttext: Got it  okay. I'm just trying to get my arms around -- I mean, MAIT -- the transmission in the Eastern part of your service territories seems like a huge opportunity in terms of the rate base growth there. I'm just trying to get my arms around kind of the magnitude of the impact over time. One other question for you. [indiscernible], where do you see the greatest opportunities across your businesses to manage further down and you've done a really good job over the last year or so in doing so. Where do you see the incremental opportunities and where potentially are there headwinds?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think of it necessarily as managing O&M down. I think about it as spending the appropriate amount of O&M to serve our customers the right way. As we invest in new equipment, O&M is going to trend down. In the transmission system, we'll repla
componenttext: Well, I don't think of it necessarily as managing O&M down. I think about it as spending the appropriate amount of O&M to serve our customers the right way. As we invest in new equipment, O&M is going to trend down. In the transmission system, we'll replace 60 and 70 year older equipment with brand-new equipment that as I've shared before, we're basically buying with 30 year warranties from the manufacturer, full warranties where we don't have to do any O&M on them. So we're going to spend the appropriate O&M as long as were having rate cases and we're having timely recovery of our expenses, I think the shareholders are immune to how much O&M is involved. And so when we think about it, it's more about where do we spend it, how is it be recovered and is it the right amount for customers?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're showing time for 1 additional question today. Our last question will be coming from Praful Mehta of Citigroup.
componenttext: We're showing time for 1 additional question today. Our last question will be coming from Praful Mehta of Citigroup.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered. Just quickly  on strategic direction and M&A. I guess, if the Ohio PPA goes 1 way or the other, does that change your view around how you think about M&A in general. Certainly, a lot of M&A that happened last year
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. Just quickly  on strategic direction and M&A. I guess, if the Ohio PPA goes 1 way or the other, does that change your view around how you think about M&A in general. Certainly, a lot of M&A that happened last year continues to be a lot of M&A this year. So if you could just broadly now that you're going more towards a regulated platform and as you said, you are a regulated utility, how are you thinking about strategic direction in M&A in that market?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, of all the things I've been thinking about as CEO the last 16 months, M&A is not high on that priority, that's how I would answer that. We're trying to strengthen the company that we know. We're a big company. We have 6 million customers to serve. W
componenttext:
Well, of all the things I've been thinking about as CEO the last 16 months, M&A is not high on that priority, that's how I would answer that. We're trying to strengthen the company that we know. We're a big company. We have 6 million customers to serve. We're going to do that the right way. 
Okay, before we leave you, I have 1 final announcement that I'd like to make. Many of you know Ray Jimenez. Ray has been part of our IR team at FirstEnergy since 1997 and he's decided that he'd rather spend his time in retirement than talking to all of you in the future. So he's going to be retiring after 39 years with the company. He'll be in the office until early June and I'd encourage you, I know many of you have worked with him to get a chance to wish hi the, best as we will for a healthy and happy retirement. So just wanted to make that announcement. Thank you all again for your support and confidence and we'll be talking to you again as soon as we have an answer from FERC.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation. This concludes today's teleconference. You may disconnect your lines at this time, and have a wonderful day.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Meghan Beringer, Director, Investor Re
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Meghan Beringer, Director, Investor Relations for FirstEnergy Corp. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donna, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's first quarter earnings call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current exp
componenttext:
Thank you, Donna, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's first quarter earnings call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such statements can be found on the Investors section of our website under the Earnings Information link and in our SEC filings. 
We will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are also available on the website. Please note that we have also provided a slide presentation that will follow this morning's discussion. 
If you are currently on the Investors page of our website or plan to visit at a later time, you will notice that we have redesigned the site to provide a more user-friendly experience, particularly on mobile devices. Also, based on your feedback, we created an Investor Materials section located on the Investor menu for easier access to information you most frequently use. 
As for today's call, those who are participating include: Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Leila Vespoli, Executive Vice President, Markets and Chief Legal Officer; Donny Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; Jon Taylor, Vice President, Controller and Chief Accounting Officer; Steve Staub, Vice President and Treasurer; and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations. Now I'd like to turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. We're off to a strong start in 2016, and I'm pleased to share this update with you today. Yesterday afternoon, we reported solid operating earnings of $0.80 per share, which is at the midpoint
componenttext:
Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. We're off to a strong start in 2016, and I'm pleased to share this update with you today. Yesterday afternoon, we reported solid operating earnings of $0.80 per share, which is at the midpoint of our first quarter guidance. On a GAAP basis, earnings were $0.78 per share. 
While Jim will review our financial results in more detail, I want to quickly mention that we've produced quality results and met our operating earnings guidance despite the impact of an unseasonably mild winter and low power prices. The successful implementation of our economic dispatch strategy was key to that outcome because the fuel savings that resulted from idling some units, when market prices did not support them, helped to offset the other impacts of mild temperatures across the company, particularly in our distribution business. 
In addition to meeting our financial commitments to you, we continue to implement our regulated growth strategies. We have several positive developments on that front and we will provide more detail today on our next steps to ensure continued service reliability for our customers, with appropriate recovery of our investments. Let's start in Ohio where the Public Utilities Commission completed a comprehensive, nearly 2-year review of our Powering Ohio's Progress electric security plan and unanimously approved the plan with certain modifications. 
The PUCO concluded that the approved plan promotes rate stability and retail competition and adds value for Ohio customers, communities and the environment. I would both like to complement and thank our public utilities commissioners and staff for their leadership in handling a very complex regulatory matter. I am proud of this ESP and of the entire team that worked on it. The plan helps safeguard customers against rising energy prices in future years while preserving key power plants that serve Ohio customers, ensuring fuel diversity and maintaining Ohio jobs. 
In addition, it outlines steps to support low income customers, reinstates energy efficiency programs, evaluate smart grid technologies and includes the goal to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. It truly fulfills the principles that the Ohio legislature outlined for the electric security plans when they moved the state toward retail competition. 
Clearly, it's been a long and conscientious process to get to this point, and while PUCO approval is a critical milestone, there are still challenges at FERC. Our opponents have also expressed their intent to bring court challenges. I will quickly review our position on these issues, and Leila can address your additional questions during the Q&A. 
First, we believe FERC should have affirm the waiver that is already in place. You recall that FES was granted authorization from FERC to conduct certain transactions with our Ohio utilities in 2008. Our purchase power agreement is one of those transactions. It was carefully constructed from the beginning to comply with existing FERC rules that promote customer shopping for retail energy supply and it will not hinder the PJM market's ability to function and foster competition. 
A separate complaint asked FERC to enclose a price floor on the PPA units for the May 2016, PJM RPM capacity auction. We don't believe there's any reason for our PPA units to be treated differently than any of the other regulated generation in PJM. It's no secret that a significant amount of generation, both regulated and merchant, has been offered in the prior PJM options with price-taking behavior. Some of these complainants are likely in that group of suppliers. What they are asking FERC to do is essentially have FirstEnergy protect them from themselves. We have filed a strong answer, demonstrating that the price floor is not needed and challenging the economic theory behind the opposition's price floor methodology, and we do not expect that FERC will impose a price floor on the PPA units for the upcoming option. 
With regards to the other potential challenges, we believe that PUCO's decision is well within the commissions authority and we expect it will withstand subsequent challenges. Furthermore, the notion of non-bypass-able charges on Ohio utility bills is not new as charges for programs such as energy efficiency, economic development and low-income support as well as cost to support the bulk transmission system have been in place for years. 
Given that FERC could make an announcement on the issues before there very soon, we're holding off on providing a second quarter operating earnings guidance. Once we do have additional clarity from FERC, we expect to have a better picture of our full-year 2016 outlook and we will offer you further details and guidance. I know this decision may seem inconsistent with our stated objective to improve transparency and disclosures. We remain committed to giving you the information you need to evaluate our company when we know it. ESP is simply too significant to speculate on its outcome. 
While we do anticipate filing for rehearing on the ESP floor by May 2, to address a few items of clarification, we are moving forward to implement the PPA that was entered into on April 1. As you know, our regulated generation group has experienced selling the output for Mon Power's regulated units at Fort Martin and Harrison into PJM. They're using that experience and have retained a leading industry consultant to help prepare strategies and offer formation for the Davis-Besse and Sammis plants in advance of the May PJM capacity option. 
The regulated team plans to sell the output from Davis-Besse and Sammis into PJM as of June 1. We're also laying the groundwork to meet the provisions outlined in the terms of the ESP floor. In late February, we submitted our grid modernization business plan, which outlined a menu of options for the PUCO. We also filed our energy efficiency plan with the commission earlier this month, and by November 1, we will file a carbon reduction report that outlines our fuel diversification and carbon reduction strategies. 
In ESP, we proposed CO2 reduction goal of at least 90% below 2005 levels by 2045, building on the 25% reduction of CO2 emissions already achieved across our footprint. This goal represents a potential reduction of more than 80 million tons of CO2 emissions and is among the most aggressive targets in the utility industry. 
In support of our commitment to a cleaner energy future, we launched a branding campaign in February called The Switch is On. This campaign highlights our environmental achievements, transition to a cleaner energy sources and our green electricity options. Earlier this month, we entered into a unique green energy pact with the Cleveland Indians to provide Progressive Field with 100% Green-e certified wind energy from FirstEnergy Solutions. 
We also introduced an Earth Day promotion, inviting Ohio and Pennsylvania residents to sign up for 100% wind energy at the same price as the standard energy offer. 
Turning to other regulatory matters. Our proposed mid-Atlantic interstate transmission subsidiary, known as MAIT, received FERC approval in late February. As we have discussed, this subsidiary would hold the transmission assets of Met-Ed, Penelec and JCP&L and facilitate new investments that can improve service reliability for these customers. 
Earlier this month, the Pennsylvania ALJs issued an initial decision, approving a settlement filed by the parties resolving all issues in this case. We anticipate final approval from the Pennsylvania PUC by midyear. And last week, we made a supplemental filing in New Jersey seeking to transfer certain JCP&L distribution assets into MAIT, which we believe should satisfy the concerns regarding public utility status that were addressed by the BPU in February. We will continue to work with the BPU because we believe transferring these assets to MAIT is the right thing to do for our New Jersey customers. 
As we mentioned in February, we are past the halfway point of the first phase of our Energizing the Future transmission investment program, with $2.4 billion invested through 2015 on projects designed to make our system more robust, secure and resistant to extreme weather events. This program remains on track and we continue to view the transmission business as our primary growth platform for many years to come. Over the past 2 years, we have been focused on removing regulatory uncertainty and positioning our regulated businesses for growth. Tomorrow, we plan to file rate cases for JCP&L and our 4 Pennsylvania utilities that are consistent with our goals of enhancing customer service and reliability, strengthening the distribution system, improving security and adding resiliency and operating flexibility to our infrastructure while providing stability and growth for the company. 
In Pennsylvania, our 4 utilities will file rate plans with the Public Utilities Commission, aimed at extending the service reliability improvement efforts that have yielded significant results for more than 2 million customers. Since 2011, the number of power outage impacting our Pennsylvania customers has decreased by an average of about 27% while restoration times have improved by an average of about 14% in that same period. In total, our request will result in an expected revenue increase totaling $430 million across 4 Pennsylvania utilities and we've broken down the impact by operating company in the Appendix of our slide presentation. 
These changes would bring the average monthly bills in line with the typical residential bills for the other 3 major electric utilities in the state while benefiting customers by modernizing the grid with smart technologies, increased vegetation management activities and continuing customer service enhancements. 
Pending PUC approval, we anticipate that the new rates will take effect in January of 2017. The new base rates at the Pennsylvania utilities will also include recovery of costs associated with our long-term infrastructure improvement plans, which include a projected increase in capital investments of $245 million over 5 years to help strengthened upgrade and modernize our Pennsylvania distribution systems. We expect to begin recovering the cost of those programs in July through the distribution system improvement charges that are currently pending Pennsylvania PUC approval. 
We also plan to file a rate plan with the New Jersey BPU that supports and builds on a significant service reliability improvements made by JCP&L in recent years. The planned $142 million rate request seeks to improve service and benefit customers by supporting equipment maintenance, vegetation management and inspection of lines, poles and substations while also compensating for other business and operating expenses. The JCP&L plan is to designed to extend the service reliability improvements to help the utility achieve its best service reliability record in more than a decade last year. While JCP&L's rates have remained stable and even declined over the past decade, our operating expenses have continued to increase. Since July 2012, JCP&L has invested $612 million in service-related enhancement projects. And even with the proposed 6% overall rate increase for the average residential customer, JCP&L would continue to offer the lowest residential electric rates among the 4 regulated electric distribution companies in New Jersey. 
You will remember that our last rate case in New Jersey, which was based on a 2011 test year, was complicated due to storm recovery expense issues and other items. In the upcoming proceeding, which satisfies the BPU requirement that we file a new rate case by April of 2017, we hope for a reasonable time line and recognition of the significant investments we have made. Allowing for a thorough review of our filing, we will request the new rates to go into effect in January of 2017. 
We remain focused on continuing to position our company for growth and success to best serve our customers, communities, investors and employees. 
Now, I would turn the call over to Jim for his review of the quarter and as always, we will have plenty of time for your questions at the end of his remarks.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. I will remind you that detailed information about the quarter can be found in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening and as always, we welcome your questions during the Q&A or fo
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. I will remind you that detailed information about the quarter can be found in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening and as always, we welcome your questions during the Q&A or following the call. 
I'm sure you've also noticed that we did not publish a full FactBook this quarter. We hope to have greater clarity regarding the PPA shortly, which would hopefully allow us to have an analyst meeting and provide full guidance for 2016. In place of the FactBook, we have included an Appendix to the slides for today's call, with certain regulatory and financial updates we would normally published each quarter. 
Our first quarter operating earnings of $0.80 per share compares to $0.62 per share in the first quarter of 2015. On a GAAP basis, we recorded earnings of $0.78 per share for the first quarter of 2016 compared to $0.53 per basic share during the same period last year. 2016 first quarter GAAP results include special items totaling $0.02 per share, which includes regulatory charges primarily related to economic development and energy efficiency programs associated with the Ohio ESP commitments, offset by mark-to-market gains on commodity contracts. A full listing of special items can be found on Page 2 of the consolidated report. 
In our distribution business, results were impacted primarily by mild temperatures on distribution deliveries and lower rates in New Jersey that went into effect in 2015, partially offset by the benefit of Pennsylvania rates that were also implemented last year. Total distribution deliveries decreased 7.8% compared to the first quarter of 2015, with a 13.4% decrease in residential sales and a 5.1% decrease in commercial sales, reflecting heating degree days that were 25% below last year and 11% below normal. 
On a weather-adjusted basis, residential deliveries were essentially flat while commercial deliveries decreased 1.6%. Sales to industrial customers decreased 2.8%. We do continue to see growth in shale gas sector, but the rate has slowed dramatically in the past 2 years and is not enough to offset lower usage from steel and coal mining activity. 
First quarter industrial load was off nearly 110 gigawatt hours as a result of reduced operations at Republic Steel, which then announced an indefinite shutdown on April 1 and the permanent closure of Warren Steel. Overall, our sales are following the national trend that was noted by the Energy Information Association earlier this year. Weather-adjusted residential and commercial sales are each down more than 1% over the past 4 quarters while industrial load is down 3% in that time frame. Drivers include the impact of more efficient lighting, appliances and equipment and slowing and shifting economic growth. 
In our transmission business, operating earnings increased as a result of the higher rate base at ATSI, partially offset by the lower return on equity that was part of ATSI's comprehensive settlement approved by FERC last fall. 
In our competitive business, strong first quarter earnings reflect an increase in commodity margin, which primarily benefited from higher capacity revenues driven by increased capacity prices, as well as lower purchase power expense, higher wholesale sales and lower fossil fuel expense. These factors offset lower contract sales volume, which decreased in line with our hedging strategy. A decrease in fossil fuel expense relates to lower fuel rates. And as Chuck indicated earlier, it also reflects the benefits of our economic dispatch strategy, which kept the Bruce Mansfield Plant offline for part of February and March. This strategy is the right approach at this time, and we will continue to deploy it if markets don't support plant operations. Clearly, this remains a very challenging business environment for our competitive units as prices continued to drop. 
Although we are not updating our CES-adjusted EBITDA guidance at this time, we note that a reduction of about $3 per megawatt hour in the round-the-clock prices, since the beginning of this year, translates into a reduction of more than $50 million in wholesale revenues. 
Our committed sales are about 62 million-megawatt hours for 2016, with an additional 12 million-megawatt-hours as part of the Ohio PPA. In 2017, we have 42 million megawatt-hours committed, with an additional 20 megawatt-hours for the Ohio PPA. We are reaffirming our expectation that the competitive business will be cash flow positive each year through at least 2018. 
And finally, at corporate, a higher consolidated income tax rate and other expenses reduced operating earnings by $0.02 per share compared to the first quarter of 2015. As Chuck said, we are off to a very solid start in 2016 and we are very encouraged by the developments in Ohio and remain committed to providing customer focused growth and creating long-term value for our shareholders. 
Now I'd like to open the call up for your questions.

componenttext: Jonathan, this is Jim. Let me take a shot at it then I'll let Leila get into more detail if we need. First off, we're going to have an increase in our rate base. So that will be part of it. We also have increased depreciation expense associated with our investments. We're also rolling in the DISC writer as part of this increase. As I would say that there was not a defined ROE last year in the Pennsylvania case. So it's hard to say if we're tracking to that. But overall, I'd say our earnings in Pennsylvania are doing well, but because of these significant investments as well as the decrease in sales and the DISC writer, now that is leading to the increase. And Leila, I don't know if you have anything to add to that?

componenttextpreview: Well, I think our game plan is to wait and see what FERC does. If it drags on too long, then my expectation is we'll give you guidance for 2016, without the ESP baked into it. That would be our plan. If -- I don't expect this is going to drag on a long ti
componenttext: Well, I think our game plan is to wait and see what FERC does. If it drags on too long, then my expectation is we'll give you guidance for 2016, without the ESP baked into it. That would be our plan. If -- I don't expect this is going to drag on a long time. There's a lot of speculation out there that they'll make a decision before the May RPM. That doesn't bother me so much as they don't because a lot of the opponents' cases suggesting that we're going to do something inappropriate in how we bid these units. And once they see how we bid these units, then I think that would diffuse a lot of that argument. So if it waits until after the RPM, that wouldn't bother me too much. But beyond that, I think if it continues to go on, then we're going to give you guidance for 2016 without the ESP.

componenttext: Well, we're not going to talk about our bidding behavior, but I think it's something that FERC can look at. If they just look at how we bid our West Virginia plants in the last RP -- or actually, since capacity performance, they could see a very good indication of how we bid units on the regulated side, and we haven't disclosed that bidding behavior and we don't plan to. But my point is this: I don't think that -- I think there's a lot of rhetoric going on about how these PPAs might affect the capacity market. It's nothing but rhetoric. This PPA has no impact on the PJM market whatsoever.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Leila. Given the high profile, I guess, my view on this would be that they would be looking at both these cases before the base residual auction just to give clarity. From the way I view the world, if you think about the affiliate waiver cas
componenttext: Paul, this is Leila. Given the high profile, I guess, my view on this would be that they would be looking at both these cases before the base residual auction just to give clarity. From the way I view the world, if you think about the affiliate waiver case, if I'm the chairman, he looks at things from a legalistic standpoint. I kind of view things that same way. And so I have a case in front of me where there are strong precedents not to look behind the screen, if you would, to what the states are doing. He has, in the initial 2008 waiver, there was a claim by NOPEC that non-bypass-able charges should be looked at and should cause them to say that they're not -- not all the customers -- that they are captive customers. They chose not to make that finding, so they go against us and grant the complaint. He would have to go against legal precedent. I don't see him doing that and I think he would want to get that out of the way, and that's tied to most of complaint because, fundamentally, they're kind of looking to address "the same issue." And if you look at the Moser [ph] complaints, there are a lot of parties with -- that wade in with a lot of different potential remedies. And I don't think they're going to fall prey to the hyperbole especially out there by Dargy [ph], that there's a burning platform, that there's imminent danger, that they're going to want to act and give clarity and take their time and look at this. So from my standpoint, I think they're going to want to act on the waiver. I think they're going to deny the complaint because I think it's -- and to do otherwise would be inconsistent with past precedent. They can take care of the issues supposedly involved in that complaint, in the Moser [ph] complaints. I think they can do so in a very thoughtful way by addressing it through the stakeholder process, what they're used to dealing with it and taking care of it in the next -- for the next BRA auction in 2017. Because I wanted to give clarity to the market in that regard.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe a question directed to Leila. So the Supreme Court ruling in Maryland obviously, net-net most saw it as a negative but obviously, some of the justices gave some guidance around what would be, from a legal stand
componenttext: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe a question directed to Leila. So the Supreme Court ruling in Maryland obviously, net-net most saw it as a negative but obviously, some of the justices gave some guidance around what would be, from a legal standpoint, possible. They clearly give us some distinctions between Maryland and New Jersey versus what you're proposing on Ohio. So I'd like to get maybe your opinion here on what you thought of the Supreme Court ruling?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Net-net, I actually think it's quite positive. So you may recall the Maryland case was out there when we first constructed the PPA, so we knew we were kind of threading the needle with regard to that. And I think the Supreme Court's decision confirms that
componenttext: Net-net, I actually think it's quite positive. So you may recall the Maryland case was out there when we first constructed the PPA, so we knew we were kind of threading the needle with regard to that. And I think the Supreme Court's decision confirms that we did a good job of that. The decision in and of itself does not negatively impact it. In fact, if you look at one of the footnotes, they go into a long, detailed description of the traditional bilateral contract, which mirrors directly our PPAs. So from a structure standpoint, if you think about it, through that footnote, they signaled that the structure that the PPA is something that is out for the market and that they feel comfortable with. So structurally, I think it is -- it meets the test. And then if you go back to the EPSA case, albeit they made a statement that insulating retail customers from price fluctuations is something that falls under state authority. So if what the commission's purpose was, was appropriate for EPSA and the structure is appropriate per the Hughes [ph] decision, I think, again those 2 together present us a very strong case with regard to any Federal District court case that might be brought our way.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So it's just fair to say that if something -- if you get a negative outcome at FERC and this does get taken up by the Supreme Court, it's a pretty good standing?
componenttext: Got it. So it's just fair to say that if something -- if you get a negative outcome at FERC and this does get taken up by the Supreme Court, it's a pretty good standing?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's an excellent standing. Thank you.
componenttext: I think it's an excellent standing. Thank you.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. Okay, good. And then just one last question, Chuck, on sort of haven't had an update on the equity, but if FERC decides to take up this case and sort of gets thrown out a little bit. How should we sort of think about your equity needs?
componenttext: Excellent. Okay, good. And then just one last question, Chuck, on sort of haven't had an update on the equity, but if FERC decides to take up this case and sort of gets thrown out a little bit. How should we sort of think about your equity needs?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you should think about it the way I've been answering it for the last 1.5 years and that is we can't make a determination until we have all these answers. And I don't expect that it's going to be a lengthy FERC process so -- and my position from t
componenttext: I think you should think about it the way I've been answering it for the last 1.5 years and that is we can't make a determination until we have all these answers. And I don't expect that it's going to be a lengthy FERC process so -- and my position from the beginning has been, it's our obligation to structure this company and operate in a way where we can get our credit issues behind us without having to use equity to do that . We're talking to you about a lot of growth opportunities on the regulated distribution and transmission side, assuming we get successfully done with MAIT. That opens up more transmission investment, and I'm not going to be embarrassed to tell you we want to use equity to help grow this company going forward, but the amount and the timing, I'm not ready to discuss.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Neel Mitra of Tudor Pickering.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Neel Mitra of Tudor Pickering.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a general question on the distribution strategy going forward. With lower sales growth, is the strategy to continue to file regular rate cases to compensate you for the increased spend? Or in some jurisdictions, are you looking to implement some sor
componenttext: I had a general question on the distribution strategy going forward. With lower sales growth, is the strategy to continue to file regular rate cases to compensate you for the increased spend? Or in some jurisdictions, are you looking to implement some sort of formula rate plans like you are with the DISC mechanism in Pennsylvania?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would answer that we have 5 different distribution strategies. We serve in 5 states. They all have different regulatory treatments. Under the Ohio ESP, we have an extension of the DCR through the term. We also have a new treatment for smart grid a
componenttext: Well, I would answer that we have 5 different distribution strategies. We serve in 5 states. They all have different regulatory treatments. Under the Ohio ESP, we have an extension of the DCR through the term. We also have a new treatment for smart grid and smart meter type investments. So there's a different regulatory strategy in Ohio than Pennsylvania. Pennsylvania, we've got the LTIP and the DISCs. And obviously, we're filing for rate cases there and in New Jersey. West Virginia, we had a case last year. If we get into a position where we need another case, we'll file it. And In Maryland, quite frankly, the growth in load has been commensurate with our investments and there's been no need to file a case there. So I think it's 5 different strategies. Overall though, I would tell you the strategy is to start making the investments needed to improve the service to our customers beyond where we're at, to provide more security to the distribution network and basically make investments to serve our customers better. And then, do them in a way where we can communicate to you how we're going to get the returns.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then my second question was on the competitive generation side and the sensitivity to the open position. Can you remind us roughly how many terawatt-hours or what percentage of your expected generation that you plan to keep open in any given y
componenttext: Got it. And then my second question was on the competitive generation side and the sensitivity to the open position. Can you remind us roughly how many terawatt-hours or what percentage of your expected generation that you plan to keep open in any given year?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Donny, Neel. Without the PPA, we have our FactBook, which show we have about 17 terawatt-hours open for '16. Jim talked about the fact that $3 move on that 17 terawatt-hours would be about a $50 million impact. With the PPA, if the PPA goes forwar
componenttext: This is Donny, Neel. Without the PPA, we have our FactBook, which show we have about 17 terawatt-hours open for '16. Jim talked about the fact that $3 move on that 17 terawatt-hours would be about a $50 million impact. With the PPA, if the PPA goes forward, we actually chew up some of that open position as we look through the end of '16.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, got it. And then just last point of clarification. On Pennsylvania, you said you're going to implement the DISC structure with this rate case. Would that help basically lengthen out the period between rate cases? Or is that just for a small po
componenttext: Okay. Okay, got it. And then just last point of clarification. On Pennsylvania, you said you're going to implement the DISC structure with this rate case. Would that help basically lengthen out the period between rate cases? Or is that just for a small portion of the distribution spend going forward?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So actually, the DISC -- we filed for the DISC effective July 1 to start treating the first investments in our long-term infrastructure plan. And under this rate case, any DISC expenditures up to that point would be rolled into the base rates and then we
componenttext: So actually, the DISC -- we filed for the DISC effective July 1 to start treating the first investments in our long-term infrastructure plan. And under this rate case, any DISC expenditures up to that point would be rolled into the base rates and then we have the option going forward to then use the DISC in real-time to recover investments in the long-term infrastructure plan in the out years. So we filed to invest $245 million over the next 5 years. So we're going to use both.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Brian Chin of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Brian Chin of Merrill Lynch.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the earlier equity issuance question just in a little bit more specific way. Can you provide your latest thoughts on timing or amount with regards to equity issuance just for transmission purposes and particularly if FERC is
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the earlier equity issuance question just in a little bit more specific way. Can you provide your latest thoughts on timing or amount with regards to equity issuance just for transmission purposes and particularly if FERC is going to be delaying its response to the PPA question, does it make sense to potentially separate your equity issuance for transmission and not make that contingent on timing with FERC?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so I talked about in my comments, the fact that we're halfway through Energizing the Future, we've invested $2.4 billion in our transmission over the last 2 years with no equity and during a time that we were working to kind of strengthen our cash f
componenttext: Well, so I talked about in my comments, the fact that we're halfway through Energizing the Future, we've invested $2.4 billion in our transmission over the last 2 years with no equity and during a time that we were working to kind of strengthen our cash flows in order to improve our credit metrics. We've got 2 more years of that program at about $1 billion a year. I don't see any equity needed to fund that transmission growth. Going forward, if we plan to expand our transmission investment program or expand significantly what we're doing in the distribution, then any equity needs would be associated with increased investment in T&D. So I answered the same way. We're not prepared to say what that amount is, but I don't think you need to be worried about Energizing the Future being taken off-track in any case.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So following up perhaps where we started on the rate cases. Can you remind us where we stand on earned ROEs and kind of a trailing basis for '15? Just -- I supposed speaking to the rate case filing itself or whatever you have out there, both New Jersey an
componenttext: So following up perhaps where we started on the rate cases. Can you remind us where we stand on earned ROEs and kind of a trailing basis for '15? Just -- I supposed speaking to the rate case filing itself or whatever you have out there, both New Jersey and Pennsylvania just -- and perhaps on a prospective basis, the purpose for the case, at least in Jersey, seems to be recovering O&M. And then, separately Pennsylvania seems principally driven by the implementation of the DISC and spending investment there. Is that kind of a good way to [indiscernible] respectively?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Jim. I would say that in Pennsylvania, it's primarily driven by somewhat the decrease in the load. It's part of the DISC filing we have. There's also additional investments that we've made there. We've got a very large smart meter implemen
componenttext: Julien, this is Jim. I would say that in Pennsylvania, it's primarily driven by somewhat the decrease in the load. It's part of the DISC filing we have. There's also additional investments that we've made there. We've got a very large smart meter implementation program going on over there. So that's primarily what's driving that in Pennsylvania. You're also able to file on a forward-looking test year. When I look at New Jersey, it's primarily driven by a significant amount of investment that we've made since the last test year in New Jersey, and that was 2011. And as we said in our remarks, since July of 2012, we've had a significant amount of capital investment and why we say partway through 2012 because in the test year in New Jersey, you're allowed to claim in-service amounts for 6 months after the in-service state. So we've had a significant amount of investment in New Jersey. So that's what's driving that. Again, as far as our overall return on equity within each of the states, I would say that we're probably tracking right around where we should based on the last rate proceeding. However, as you know in Pennsylvania, they did not publish what the ROE was in the settlement.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Leila. The only thing that I would add, when you're speaking about Pennsylvania, think about aggressive energy efficiency measures and no lost distribution or recoveries. So when Jim was talking about the lower revenue, those factors play
componenttext: Julien, this is Leila. The only thing that I would add, when you're speaking about Pennsylvania, think about aggressive energy efficiency measures and no lost distribution or recoveries. So when Jim was talking about the lower revenue, those factors play into that.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then turning to the equity piece of the equation, just to be clear on setting expectations. We shouldn't expect to hear from you on equity until you get a definitive decision either rejects or accept the waiver -- not the waiver, but the decis
componenttext: Got it. And then turning to the equity piece of the equation, just to be clear on setting expectations. We shouldn't expect to hear from you on equity until you get a definitive decision either rejects or accept the waiver -- not the waiver, but the decision outright from FERC, and no action from the credit rating agencies correspondingly until that as well.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

componenttext: I would say yes.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Chris Turnure of JPMorgan.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we could talk a little bit about the supply set of the business and x the PPA. If you just look at the performance over the past couple of quarters, I think specifically excluding the change in capacity prices and excluding the change i
componenttext: I was wondering if we could talk a little bit about the supply set of the business and x the PPA. If you just look at the performance over the past couple of quarters, I think specifically excluding the change in capacity prices and excluding the change in the volume, you've had a pretty noticeable improvement there despite a decline in commodity prices, maybe you could just flush that out a little bit more and give us color there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start then I'll let Donny add to it. During 2015, we talked with you about our cash flow improvement program. Much of that was focused on the competitive business and much of that was focused on getting our competitiveness to the point where it
componenttext: Well, I'll start then I'll let Donny add to it. During 2015, we talked with you about our cash flow improvement program. Much of that was focused on the competitive business and much of that was focused on getting our competitiveness to the point where it continues to be cash flow positive and has no need for any cash from the parent through 2018, at current energy prices as we know them. So part of that was also targeted at the FFO from that generation business, so we reduced O&M expenditures, which contributed to some of what you're seeing there. So that's kind of from an operational perspective. The thing that Jim Lash and his generation team have done to improve the competitiveness of that business. I'll let Donny talk a little bit about the commodity side.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I just add, obviously, we have taken a position starting after the polar vortex in '14 to derisk the business and to move away from weather-sensitive load. You'll recall in the first quarter for '15, we had what's been referred to as the Siberian Exp
componenttext: Yes. I just add, obviously, we have taken a position starting after the polar vortex in '14 to derisk the business and to move away from weather-sensitive load. You'll recall in the first quarter for '15, we had what's been referred to as the Siberian Express. And while it was not nearly as significant of an impact to FES as the polar vortex, it still had some impact. I'm happy to report this past quarter, although we had very mild weather, the fact that we have much less weather-sensitive load, our results were pretty much in line with our expectations from a sales perspective.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Donny and his team are doing a fantastic job running that business too. Back in February when we had Mansfield off for 2 weeks, the entire plant off, there were several sell side notes that suggested that meant that load was down and we were going to have
componenttext: Donny and his team are doing a fantastic job running that business too. Back in February when we had Mansfield off for 2 weeks, the entire plant off, there were several sell side notes that suggested that meant that load was down and we were going to have a bad quarter. In reality that's part of how we're dispatching those units differently. So we don't run them when we can't make money with them. So I talked in my remarks about that, saved us fuel. So Donny is doing a great job at looking at every day, every hour, how do we maximize that business under some very difficult economic times.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean to that point, is there anything that we should think about historically that's forced you to run units that were uneconomic such as mandatory take or pay coal contracts or something of that nature that would be rolling off this year or in th
componenttext: Okay. I mean to that point, is there anything that we should think about historically that's forced you to run units that were uneconomic such as mandatory take or pay coal contracts or something of that nature that would be rolling off this year or in the future to kind of provide a tailwind for your numbers all else equal? Or am I barking up the wrong tree there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Donny.
componenttext: Go ahead, Donny.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we've had coal contracts in place for a lot of years that gives us significant flexibility. This isn't really something new for us. I think the degree is much greater now, but you'll recall back in 2000 -- I believe it was 2012, around August 2012
componenttext: I mean, we've had coal contracts in place for a lot of years that gives us significant flexibility. This isn't really something new for us. I think the degree is much greater now, but you'll recall back in 2000 -- I believe it was 2012, around August 2012, we took the entire Sammis plant down and kept it offline through December. So it's not really new. I think the difference is with the weak -- incredibly weak forward day ahead market that we're seeing, it calls in more economic dispatch than perhaps what we've seen in the past.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then shifting gears to transmission again. The rejection by New Jersey of your utility status for the MAIT request. It would seem on the surface to be a significant setback, but your comments have indicated that you're going to continue t
componenttext: Okay, great. And then shifting gears to transmission again. The rejection by New Jersey of your utility status for the MAIT request. It would seem on the surface to be a significant setback, but your comments have indicated that you're going to continue to push forward and you think it's very important. Could you may be characterize how important the New Jersey part of the MAIT program is to the overall transmission spend and the levels going forward and growth going forward and the timing now that you've had the setback? If been kind of adjusted at all in New Jersey?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first I would say, I think MAIT is very important to our customers in New Jersey and we have to do a better good job of helping the BPU understand why it's important. We've done that in our latest filing and we'll continue to work with them to get
componenttext: Yes. So first I would say, I think MAIT is very important to our customers in New Jersey and we have to do a better good job of helping the BPU understand why it's important. We've done that in our latest filing and we'll continue to work with them to get it across the finish line. If we don't, then we'll look at options to implement MAIT in Pennsylvania potentially but as far as your real question, in terms of how does it affect our transmission investment strategy, we've got 2 more years of Energizing the Future. We've got projects beyond that inside ATSI and TrAILCo that we can continue to move forward with. I don't see MAIT being crucial at all to our transmission investment strategy. I see it as a way to implement that transmission investment strategy in a way where we can lower the cost of capital and do it in a way that's better for customers and create more transparency for our investors. That's how I see it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Stephen Byrd of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Stephen Byrd of Morgan Stanley.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been addressed. I just wanted to focus on the Pennsylvania revenue request. When I look at the Appendix, it looks like the customer bill impacts are -- can be relatively significant. I think one of the jurisdictions it's about 18
componenttext: Most of my questions have been addressed. I just wanted to focus on the Pennsylvania revenue request. When I look at the Appendix, it looks like the customer bill impacts are -- can be relatively significant. I think one of the jurisdictions it's about 18% if I'm reading the page correctly. Is there a way to phase that in or to otherwise lessen the overall bill impact? And are there other presence we can look to in Pennsylvania in terms of just how to think about that? It looks like a fairly sizable rate impact?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, this is Jim. I would say that as we said earlier in our comments and Chuck said in his, that this will bring the average residential bill in Pennsylvania up to about what's average within the state. You'll recall we went a number of years without
componenttext: Stephen, this is Jim. I would say that as we said earlier in our comments and Chuck said in his, that this will bring the average residential bill in Pennsylvania up to about what's average within the state. You'll recall we went a number of years without increasing our rates in the state of Pennsylvania. It's also being offset by a -- from a customer perspective, it's being offset by a reduction in their overall energy component of the bill. So I don't view this as something that's going to be -- what would be described as a rate shock issue. As far as your early -- your request, no, I don't -- we don't see any mechanism out there where we would phase this in. This is just a normal type of request that we would have. And again, as Leila had pointed out earlier, there's very stringent energy efficiency requirements in the state of Pennsylvania, which is decreasingly used. So we're required to go in and pop these rates. So that's the way we're looking at it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And in terms of the magnitude of the benefit from lower energy costs, is there a way for us to get a sense for the magnitude of that benefit?
componenttext: Understood. And in terms of the magnitude of the benefit from lower energy costs, is there a way for us to get a sense for the magnitude of that benefit?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you can probably look at where our wholesale power prices have gone over the last few years, and as Donny mentioned, holds up power prices have fallen $3 already this year. So I think there was a period of time when round-the-clock power prices we
componenttext: I think you can probably look at where our wholesale power prices have gone over the last few years, and as Donny mentioned, holds up power prices have fallen $3 already this year. So I think there was a period of time when round-the-clock power prices were in the $50-plus range. And if you look at the forwards out there right now, over the next 3 years, they're probably closer to the $30 range.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to -- help in terms of trying to measure these rate cases in terms of earnings potential. componenttext: Yes, so basically when you showed us the EBITDA and then a bridge to net income or EPS for FES or CES without the PPAs, can you tell us if the assets of 3 plants -- or 2 plants that are covered by PPA, so without the PPA, would they have a positive EPS impact?

componenttext: But I mean, we're all struggling, I think, with the impact of your PPAs on your bottom line because we just don't know what's the offset from the current earnings power of these assets. That's why I'm asking.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand you're struggling with it and I understand that the estimates are all over the board for what does ESP means. And believe me, as soon as we can give you clarification, we plan to do that. Once we have an answer from FERC, we will tell you wha
componenttext: I understand you're struggling with it and I understand that the estimates are all over the board for what does ESP means. And believe me, as soon as we can give you clarification, we plan to do that. Once we have an answer from FERC, we will tell you what the value of this company is going forward with the ESP. If we don't have an answer, then we're going to give you 2016 guidance without the ESP. And I apologize that we're leaving you hanging out there, but it's just too big a moving part for us to speculate on the outcome.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Just most of the questions have been answered, just want to follow up. headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we are a regulated utility. 90-plus percent of our earnings today come from our regulated operations. What we're talking about is growth in investment inside that regulated utility. We filed our integrated resource plan with West Virgi
componenttext: Well, first of all, we are a regulated utility. 90-plus percent of our earnings today come from our regulated operations. What we're talking about is growth in investment inside that regulated utility. We filed our integrated resource plan with West Virginia. I think later this year, they'll start taking a look at it seriously and it's up to the West Virginia Commission to decide would Pleasants be the appropriate solution. Obviously, we have a model in place all ready with Harrison, and we think that is something they ought to look at.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Pennsylvania, is there a similar filing or similar thought process or just West Virginia?
componenttext: In Pennsylvania, is there a similar filing or similar thought process or just West Virginia?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
