componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Shar Pourreza of Guggenheim.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Chuck, in your prepared remarks, clearly somewhat of a change in strategy around merchant business. And obviously, you could tell from your tone that frustration has gone to a peak level here. I guess the first question is around the assets, is there o
componenttext: So Chuck, in your prepared remarks, clearly somewhat of a change in strategy around merchant business. And obviously, you could tell from your tone that frustration has gone to a peak level here. I guess the first question is around the assets, is there other assets that you can sort of highlight that could be potentially rationalized? And then is there a point in time where you sort of capitulate with this business, either move it to non-core or even discontinued operations at this point?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I don't think there's been any change in strategy. I think since last January, we've been talking about FirstEnergy's focus on regulated operations. And I've talked about that competitive business as obviously we own a merchant generation bus
componenttext: Well, first, I don't think there's been any change in strategy. I think since last January, we've been talking about FirstEnergy's focus on regulated operations. And I've talked about that competitive business as obviously we own a merchant generation business. We've been trying to situate it to run it more utility-like,  if you will. And I think that's paying off this year. We had a very hot period in June. And while we're not here today to talk about third quarter results, very hot July, and the strategy where we're keeping some reserve margin in that generation to protect us against rising loads is working. I think we're running it very reliably and we're making it such that it's a fairly predictable business for us even in the market that it's in. Unfortunately, the predictability is such that it's going to continue to decline in terms of the contribution it makes to the company as a whole, both in the capacity market and in the energy market. And is it frustrating that we're shutting down tens of thousands of megawatts of generation in our country that's got life left in it because of the way this market is working and that we're ignoring the fact that we have to build more transmission in order to allow the grid to work the right way when we replace it with natural gas generation that is what I call being built as energy conversion factories, not being built to serve customers? That is very frustrating to me. But nonetheless, I think we are doing the things we need to do as a company to make FirstEnergy strong even with the current merchant business that we have today. I said in my remarks that we will look at every option that's available to us that is positive from a cash and credit perspective to move out of that business over time. And that's our goal and that's kind of always been where we've been at.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's helpful. And then just on the option side, I know AEP certainly talked a lot about restructuring legislation that they're going to be going after not reregulation but restructuring. And they did highlight that they're engaged stakeholders.
componenttext: Got it, that's helpful. And then just on the option side, I know AEP certainly talked a lot about restructuring legislation that they're going to be going after not reregulation but restructuring. And they did highlight that they're engaged stakeholders. So curious, is this sort of something that you're joining AEP with? Are you one of the stakeholders? Just some color there would be good.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So right now, I think we've got a bigger issue in Ohio we're working on. And I think it's important that we keep our regulatory and legislative and legal teams focused on that issue. And that's what we're going to do. I'm aware of what AEP is proposing. I
componenttext: So right now, I think we've got a bigger issue in Ohio we're working on. And I think it's important that we keep our regulatory and legislative and legal teams focused on that issue. And that's what we're going to do. I'm aware of what AEP is proposing. I think it's a very creative approach. I think it helps solve some of the issues that we have with making sure we have reliable capacity going forward in the right places without having to build transmission on top of it. And I'm pulling for them. At the right time, we may join in with them in that effort. But at this point in time, we're not actively involved in it. We're trying to get our ESP case done.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just lastly, that's helpful, when you think about sort of your forward equity needs, not to rightsize the balance sheet as a result of whatever happens with Ohio but more from a growth perspective, should we just going forward beyond '16
componenttext: Got it. And then just lastly, that's helpful, when you think about sort of your forward equity needs, not to rightsize the balance sheet as a result of whatever happens with Ohio but more from a growth perspective, should we just going forward beyond '16 assume 50-50 cap structure on your transmission initiatives?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: From our side, we'll look at probably capitalizing the transmission segments, where the rates are set at a 60% equity level. Initially MAIT, we will have it at a 50-50 cap structure. Now obviously, at the holdco level of transmission, we will have a cap s
componenttext: From our side, we'll look at probably capitalizing the transmission segments, where the rates are set at a 60% equity level. Initially MAIT, we will have it at a 50-50 cap structure. Now obviously, at the holdco level of transmission, we will have a cap structure that's a little higher than that on the debt side. But that's how I would think about it going forward.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Neel Mitra of Tudor, Pickering and Holt.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Neel Mitra of Tudor, Pickering and Holt.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to understand how you're looking at the investment-grade metrics for the company. Are we to think that your -- you're obviously going to keep the utilities investment-grade. And it seems like you're willing to let the merchant business go to
componenttext: I just wanted to understand how you're looking at the investment-grade metrics for the company. Are we to think that your -- you're obviously going to keep the utilities investment-grade. And it seems like you're willing to let the merchant business go to sub-investment-grade. But what about the holdco or the parent? Do you plan to keep that investment-grade alongside the utilities?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And I've said that in my prepared remarks.
componenttext: Absolutely. And I've said that in my prepared remarks.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when we look to the merchant business, is it still free cash flow-positive in the outer years with the latest capacity price print and just where the forwards are right now?
componenttext: Okay. And then when we look to the merchant business, is it still free cash flow-positive in the outer years with the latest capacity price print and just where the forwards are right now?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's cash flow-positive through 2018. And we haven't talked to you about beyond that.
componenttext: It's cash flow-positive through 2018. And we haven't talked to you about beyond that.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if you were to require more capital just for the plants with the CapEx, would a sub-investment-grade entity be able to access more capital? And would you look to access capital from the markets to fund the genco markets if it was needed? Or woul
componenttext: Okay. And if you were to require more capital just for the plants with the CapEx, would a sub-investment-grade entity be able to access more capital? And would you look to access capital from the markets to fund the genco markets if it was needed? Or would you continue to find ways to basically rationalize the fleet?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Jim answer the question in detail. But I think we're confident we can raise whatever we need in order to keep that business going. In terms of refinancing existing obligations, I do not see us leveraging that business more in order to keep it goi
componenttext: I'll let Jim answer the question in detail. But I think we're confident we can raise whatever we need in order to keep that business going. In terms of refinancing existing obligations, I do not see us leveraging that business more in order to keep it going.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jim, Neel. I would agree with Chuck. As we said, that business is expected to be cash flow-positive each year through 2018. We're coming through the end of our construction phase. We'll be done with most of our match expenditures. Mansfield d
componenttext: Yes, this is Jim, Neel. I would agree with Chuck. As we said, that business is expected to be cash flow-positive each year through 2018. We're coming through the end of our construction phase. We'll be done with most of our match expenditures. Mansfield dewatering facility will be completed. And as we said, we are going to move the refueling -- or I mean, the Beaver Valley 2 steam generator and head replacement out to 2023. In addition, we have a $1.5 billion credit facility at the competitive side that we have not used. So I don't think funding that business will be any issue. However, we are going to be very focused on the capital investments and we don't intend to make any investments, especially on the fossil slide, unless it's for safety or to preserve our options going forward.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And one last quick question, we're going to get hopefully the Ohio decision wrapped up in September. And is the plan to kind of release the longer-term capital needs planned at EEI? Or is there an Analyst Day separate from that where you plan
componenttext: Okay, great. And one last quick question, we're going to get hopefully the Ohio decision wrapped up in September. And is the plan to kind of release the longer-term capital needs planned at EEI? Or is there an Analyst Day separate from that where you plan to do that?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say this, we are committed to telling you what this company looks like once we have the Ohio case done. If the timing works out for us to do that at EEI, then we'll do it at EEI. If the timing doesn't work out for that, then we'll have a mee
componenttext: Well, I would say this, we are committed to telling you what this company looks like once we have the Ohio case done. If the timing works out for us to do that at EEI, then we'll do it at EEI. If the timing doesn't work out for that, then we'll have a meeting that's specifically designed around telling you the outcome and what it does to our company, whether it's an analyst meeting or how we do that. But yes, we're going to communicate that to you as transparently as we can.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have a lot of people in the queue, and I'd like for us to be able to get through to every one today.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a lot of people in the queue, and I'd like for us to be able to get through to every one today.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold of Deutsche Bank.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just can I ask about the strategy on holding investment-grade of the parent, and you obviously have just reiterated that's a priority, and how we should view the $500 million of equity you're doing in 2016 in that context? And let's just say if you don
componenttext: So just can I ask about the strategy on holding investment-grade of the parent, and you obviously have just reiterated that's a priority, and how we should view the $500 million of equity you're doing in 2016 in that context? And let's just say if you don't get some help, what you're looking for from Ohio, can you help us think about what that scenario looks like?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think you should think about the $500 million. I mean, we told you we're going to issue $500 million of additional equity this year. Jim mentioned we've already invested over $3 billion in transmission growth capital with another $1 billion
componenttext: Well, I don't think you should think about the $500 million. I mean, we told you we're going to issue $500 million of additional equity this year. Jim mentioned we've already invested over $3 billion in transmission growth capital with another $1 billion planned next year. You all look at those numbers the same as we do. I'm not going to speculate on an outcome in Ohio right now. When we know that outcome, we will know what the impact it has on our credit ratings, and then we'll do what we need to do. We've got a number of other strategic options that we can execute that we will. But I think it's premature to talk about what all of those could or could not be until we see where we land in Ohio.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to just clarify the necessary metrics you need to get to. What do the agencies tell you in terms of the 14% of FFO to debt versus the 11% at Moody's and perhaps 12% at S&P? So just curious, to what extent does the current equity plan get you to
componenttext: So I want to just clarify the necessary metrics you need to get to. What do the agencies tell you in terms of the 14% of FFO to debt versus the 11% at Moody's and perhaps 12% at S&P? So just curious, to what extent does the current equity plan get you to something that keeps you investment-grade? And also perhaps a further nuance to the follow-up I'll just ask now, is S&P potentially enabling a 2 notch difference between your holding company and your opcos?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, when we met them earlier this week, they told us, "You guys all talk to them a whole lot more than we do." So I think it's pretty obvious out there what they expect us to get to. And in terms of how we're going to get there, I just sai
componenttext: Well, first of all, when we met them earlier this week, they told us, "You guys all talk to them a whole lot more than we do." So I think it's pretty obvious out there what they expect us to get to. And in terms of how we're going to get there, I just said the Ohio ESP is a big piece of the puzzle that we have to get answered before we can talk about what the next steps of the puzzle are. I think it's likely that both of the agencies are going to publicly say what their expectations are here in the near future both for the competitive business and for the rest of this company. But we're focused on keeping our investment-grade credit ratings at the holding company and for every one of our regulated entities.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: But said differently, just to be very clear about it, in terms of the metrics that you're targeting, are you and the agencies talking about a shift in the business risk profile? And are they ready to buy into that sort of in the near term, if you will?
componenttext: But said differently, just to be very clear about it, in terms of the metrics that you're targeting, are you and the agencies talking about a shift in the business risk profile? And are they ready to buy into that sort of in the near term, if you will?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, this is Jim. I would think that the expectation is that we'd need to achieve an FFO at 14% at this point. And they would not be looking to change that in the near term.
componenttext: Julien, this is Jim. I would think that the expectation is that we'd need to achieve an FFO at 14% at this point. And they would not be looking to change that in the near term.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, all right. And that's probably an eventual target?
componenttext: Got it, all right. And that's probably an eventual target?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As Chuck said, we ultimately intend to be a fully related company.
componenttext: Yes. As Chuck said, we ultimately intend to be a fully related company.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you can hit that FFO with the -- depending what comes out of Ohio and the $600 million in equity?
componenttext: But you can hit that FFO with the -- depending what comes out of Ohio and the $600 million in equity?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we can. We've got to wait and see what comes out of Ohio, as Chuck said.
componenttext: Yes, we can. We've got to wait and see what comes out of Ohio, as Chuck said.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Patterson of Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Patterson of Glenrock Associates.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the credit rating, I mean, normally when I think of credit rating, I think of the senior unsecured credit rating as what the focus counterparties have and what have you. And clearly, that's not what you guys are focused on, given that we already a
componenttext: Just on the credit rating, I mean, normally when I think of credit rating, I think of the senior unsecured credit rating as what the focus counterparties have and what have you. And clearly, that's not what you guys are focused on, given that we already are at below investment-grade at the senior unsecured. Is there any concern about the senior unsecured? Or is it simply focused at the issuer level? And why the focus at the issuer level as opposed to senior unsecured, which is what I normally think of as being the metric that people are -- that the rating that people are actually -- the counterparties are focused on? Do you follow me?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we follow you. From our standpoint, we're not expecting that we're going to issue any more senior unsecured debt. So I think the way we're looking at it, Paul, is we want to at least maintain where we're at right now. And our goal would be at the S&P
componenttext: Yes, we follow you. From our standpoint, we're not expecting that we're going to issue any more senior unsecured debt. So I think the way we're looking at it, Paul, is we want to at least maintain where we're at right now. And our goal would be at the S&P level to get the corporate credit rating ultimately notched up 1. That would also notch up our senior unsecured. From a Moody's standpoint, we are already at investment-grade. So that's the way we're thinking about it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Orrill with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Orrill with Barclays.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I realized you're in a case in Ohio. Can you talk about sort of the implications if the outcome ends up being something along the lines of the staff recommendation and how you would view that?
componenttext: I realized you're in a case in Ohio. Can you talk about sort of the implications if the outcome ends up being something along the lines of the staff recommendation and how you would view that?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we just filed our rebuttal testimony and attempted to point out what we thought some of the potential things that the staff missed in their testimony might be. I think some of those are pretty obvious. And even the commission staff in their testimon
componenttext: Well, we just filed our rebuttal testimony and attempted to point out what we thought some of the potential things that the staff missed in their testimony might be. I think some of those are pretty obvious. And even the commission staff in their testimony agreed that there were adjustments that were made or need to be made to the initial number they came out with. So I'm going to answer this question the way I've always answered. I'm not going to speculate about things that we don't know about. So we've got another couple of months to get through this case in Ohio. We've been waiting patiently for 2 years and 3 months to get to an outcome here. And with only a couple of months left, I'm not going to start guessing at what the outcome is. We're going to get the outcome. We're going to deal with that outcome, and then we're going to move forward and we're going to move forward in a way where we expect to maintain investment-grade credit for our holding company and all of our regulated entities.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to repeat the question. But Jim, that 14% target, is that the Moody's target? Or is that the S&P target? Or is that both?
componenttext: Sorry to repeat the question. But Jim, that 14% target, is that the Moody's target? Or is that the S&P target? Or is that both?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 14%, that's the threshold that Moody's has designed. From our standpoint, we're targeting at 14.5% to 15% of FFO. But the 14% is Moody's.
componenttext: The 14%, that's the threshold that Moody's has designed. From our standpoint, we're targeting at 14.5% to 15% of FFO. But the 14% is Moody's.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And you're also expecting rate relief in Pennsylvania and New Jersey along with hopefully a constructive outcome in Ohio. So as we think about cash flows going into '17 and beyond in the regulated businesses, you're making assumptions with regard t
componenttext: Right. And you're also expecting rate relief in Pennsylvania and New Jersey along with hopefully a constructive outcome in Ohio. So as we think about cash flows going into '17 and beyond in the regulated businesses, you're making assumptions with regard to the improvement in cash flow from all 3 of those things, right, at the equity issuance to get you to that number?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that would get us above the threshold that they've set. But again, our target is 14.5% to 15%.
componenttext: Yes, that would get us above the threshold that they've set. But again, our target is 14.5% to 15%.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And that does not presume any further equity needs post '16? Or that's sort of an iterative question relative to the total amount of rate relief you receive?
componenttext: Right. And that does not presume any further equity needs post '16? Or that's sort of an iterative question relative to the total amount of rate relief you receive?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's an iterative question. We'll continue to do the employee benefit program and stock investment program. But as Chuck said earlier, I think there's a big piece of the puzzle that still has to fall into place before we have any further considera
componenttext: I think it's an iterative question. We'll continue to do the employee benefit program and stock investment program. But as Chuck said earlier, I think there's a big piece of the puzzle that still has to fall into place before we have any further consideration there.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. One last quick thing, the $500 million you're going to issue, is that going to be issued into the pension plan? Or would that be issued directly to the public?
componenttext: Okay. One last quick thing, the $500 million you're going to issue, is that going to be issued into the pension plan? Or would that be issued directly to the public?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, as we said, this $500 million that we expect to issue, we expect to contribute that equity to our qualified pension plan.
componenttext: No, as we said, this $500 million that we expect to issue, we expect to contribute that equity to our qualified pension plan.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Turnure of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Turnure of JPMorgan.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think you covered this earlier. Maybe you could give us color on the units that were shut at Bay Shore and Sammis or are targeted to be shut and kind of where they're running right now on a kind of earnings contribution and cash flow contribution
componenttext: I don't think you covered this earlier. Maybe you could give us color on the units that were shut at Bay Shore and Sammis or are targeted to be shut and kind of where they're running right now on a kind of earnings contribution and cash flow contribution basis.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The units that we shut down or said that we were going to deactivate by 2020 was just Unit 1 at Bay Shore, the only unit we have, and it was Sammis 1 through 4 at Sammis. We've never disclosed what those would be from an earnings standpoint. But when you
componenttext: The units that we shut down or said that we were going to deactivate by 2020 was just Unit 1 at Bay Shore, the only unit we have, and it was Sammis 1 through 4 at Sammis. We've never disclosed what those would be from an earnings standpoint. But when you look at the total, including the capital that we would have to invest and the revenues net of their operating expenses, it will make us improve our cash flow going forward. And that's essentially the reason we decided to deactivate those units.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Ridzon of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Ridzon of KeyBanc.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered. But what's the timing on the equity? And have you baked July weather into your guidance?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. But what's the timing on the equity? And have you baked July weather into your guidance?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not baked July weather into the guidance. As I said in my comments on the script though, July was a very warm month and our plants ran very well. So I would expect that we will have some weather improvement in July. As far as the equity, we really
componenttext: We have not baked July weather into the guidance. As I said in my comments on the script though, July was a very warm month and our plants ran very well. So I would expect that we will have some weather improvement in July. As far as the equity, we really can't comment on the timing of the equity transaction. However, I can tell you our earnings guidance is conservative and assumes dilution starts in the earlier part of the second half of 2016.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we've planned normal weather for the rest of the half -- the second half of the year in our guidance numbers.
componenttext: And we've planned normal weather for the rest of the half -- the second half of the year in our guidance numbers.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with Wolfe Research.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the 2016 guidance. Could you give us a sense, either specific or more high level, how you're doing against your kind of allowed ROEs in your key jurisdictions within the guidance in '16? Are you kind of earning in line? Are you underear
componenttext: Just a question on the 2016 guidance. Could you give us a sense, either specific or more high level, how you're doing against your kind of allowed ROEs in your key jurisdictions within the guidance in '16? Are you kind of earning in line? Are you underearning a decent amount? Any help from that standpoint.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Jim. From my standpoint, I would say in all of our jurisdictions, we will be earning right in line with the authorized ROEs. And as you know, a few of the jurisdictions, they have what's called black-box settlement, where they don't come ou
componenttext: Steve, this is Jim. From my standpoint, I would say in all of our jurisdictions, we will be earning right in line with the authorized ROEs. And as you know, a few of the jurisdictions, they have what's called black-box settlement, where they don't come out and particularly say exactly where it is. But with the filing we have in New Jersey, the 4 utilities in Pennsylvania, where we are in Ohio, that essentially covers all of our utilities with the exception of Maryland and West Virginia. And we just had the filing in West Virginia a little over a year ago. And Maryland, we're seeing some load growth there. So I would say we're earning right in line with all of our ROEs.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'm sorry, I just want to clarify though because I was asking more specific to 2016, since we now have a base figure providing us for 2016. Since you're not getting the rate relief really by then in 2016, are you underearning a little bit, and then
componenttext: Okay, I'm sorry, I just want to clarify though because I was asking more specific to 2016, since we now have a base figure providing us for 2016. Since you're not getting the rate relief really by then in 2016, are you underearning a little bit, and then when you get the rate relief, you earn more in line? Is the rate relief mainly for growth, so you're kind of earning in line?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look in New Jersey, the rate relief is associated with our capital investments we've made since mid-2012. We've had about $600 and some million of investment there. So we're not earning on that capital right now. So I would say we're probably sligh
componenttext: If you look in New Jersey, the rate relief is associated with our capital investments we've made since mid-2012. We've had about $600 and some million of investment there. So we're not earning on that capital right now. So I would say we're probably slightly underearning there. In 2016, we would expect that we would have a decision in Pennsylvania by January 27. So our guidance would include earnings that would get us pretty near to what our ROE expectations are.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta of Citigroup.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: My quick question on the generation business, is there any intention to ring-fence that business, to protect the ratings of the holding company and the utility from what happens at the generation side?
componenttext: My quick question on the generation business, is there any intention to ring-fence that business, to protect the ratings of the holding company and the utility from what happens at the generation side?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Praful, this is Jim. I would say we're not looking at any type of new legal actions or anything to ring-fence that side of the house. The way you should look at it is there's no cross-defaults on any of the financings that we have out there or the credit
componenttext: Praful, this is Jim. I would say we're not looking at any type of new legal actions or anything to ring-fence that side of the house. The way you should look at it is there's no cross-defaults on any of the financings that we have out there or the credit facilities. FirstEnergy Corp. does guarantee about $1.25 billion on that side of the house. And it's really made up of about $1.2 billion of our underfunded pension, OPEB and EDCP cost. And then there's just about $50 million associated with some contracts that FES has. So from my standpoint, there's no thought about ring-fencing. But that's just where we are with that side of the house.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. So just to clarify, if there is a strategic action like a sale or something further down the road, where not all the debt is covered, are you looking to -- my question is are you going to support the debt? Or are you going to walk away from i
componenttext: Fair enough. componenttext: Well, I don't think that's something that we've been contemplating at this point. The business is still cash flow-positive. But I think that question is much further down the road. I was just speaking to what the guarantees are by the holding company.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take those 3 questions in there. So take the first one, and that is I've already answered it a couple of times here. We're not going to speculate about Ohio. There's a whole wide range of outcomes. The staff said one point. The corrections we m
componenttext: Well, I'll take those 3 questions in there. So take the first one, and that is I've already answered it a couple of times here. We're not going to speculate about Ohio. There's a whole wide range of outcomes. The staff said one point. The corrections we made to the staff testimony got that number up in the over $500 million. I think we've got to let that process play out, see where we're at, and then we will take whatever steps we deem are appropriate to maintain our investment-grade credit for our holding company and our utilities. And those steps are so wide-ranging depending on the outcome for Ohio, it's just -- I don't think it's good to speculate about them, so I'm not going to talk about them. I'll tell you what we know when we know it. On the second question, Jim -- I think Jim already answered it. We're not looking at doing anything to legally ring-fence our generation business. But as I said, we're not going to use any equity to support the credit ratings of that business. We're operating it in a fashion that's cash flow-positive. And we're going to make whatever decisions that we need to make on a unit-by-unit basis to deactivate them, sell them in order to keep that business as positive of a member of the FirstEnergy team as we can.
